posts.name: Saatvik
posts.cooked: Hey there! I’m currently building a 2-stage elevator for my team (612), and I was wondering how to skeletonize 1x2 Aluminum Tubestock quickly. I’ve heard you can use a plug-in in Fusion 360, but our team hasn’t skeletonized anything before so we’ve never used it. We are hoping the answer isn’t that we have to hand-CAD every piece. (We plan on CNCing the tubestock) Thank you!

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Saatvik:

but our team hasn’t skeletonized anything before so we’ve never used it

Why are you trying to skeletonize? What thickness of tube?

Aestetics are a valid answer (although for a first time I would recommend a less critical frame member, such as braces that are only 2 force members (which do not see tortional or bending loads)).

Most popular advice on here will recommend dropping down in wall thickness before skeletonizing.

posts.name: Saatvik
posts.cooked: We are using 1/8" thick 1x2 aluminum and I was thinking about trying to lose some weight on the frame of each stage

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
Yeah using thinner wall tubing is a much easier way to cut weight and likely more effective.

I’ve always skeletonized manually in CAD, it doesn’t take too long if you pick a design that stretches easily.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Here is a thread to get you started on some of the weird things that can happen when you start pocketing aggressively.

James and Alex will be able to more accurately describe some of the weird stress risers you get. (All FEA needs to be taken with a grain of salt, as they would tell you, but it is a very powerful tool)

Frc fea Technical

Elevator tubes are very critical so you need to be careful in how you approach them, they will see all sorts of loading from all manner of directions and it is almost always better to drop down in material thickness than pocket them.

You can (almost) always add more rigidity with bracing if the thinner walls are off putting.

It absolutely makes sense to think about losing weight on them though.

As far a skeletonizing in CAD - I am with Patrick - I have done it manually and patterned where I can - doesn’t take too long.

Edit: If you have existing tube plugs for 1/8th that you want to use, you can absolutely make adapters.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Build it with 2x1x1/16th wall 6051t6 aluminum tubing and be done. It’s a tried and true recipe.

If you really want to do a lightening pattern OnShape’s “Lighten” FeatureScript is easy and fast. I don’t recommend it for an elevator unless you just love making chips and weaker tubes.

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked: Is there not concerns about all stages being too thin with 1/16th wall tube? I assumed carriage and base stage on a multistage should be more rigid and 1/8th wall.

posts.name: Saatvik
posts.cooked: This makes me really want to use 1/16" now, but I’m not sure if we have nearly enough 1/16" 1x2, and ordering now would likely delay us too much. Could I get away with skeletonizing just the insides kind of like team 148 from two years ago: [ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iOh6D6haeOo ]

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Dominick_Ferone:

Is there not concerns about all stages being too thin with 1/16th wall tube? I assumed carriage and base stage on a multistage should be more rigid and 1/8th wall.

Too many design choices to generalize here. We made a decently good elevator in 2018 and 2019 with 1/16 wall tubing.

Saatvik:

This makes me really want to use 1/16" now, but I’m not sure if we have nearly enough 1/16" 1x2, and ordering now would likely delay us too much

Try a local metal supplier.

You decide you have to pocket tubing you have on hand just pocket the tube to a partial depth, like .07in deep, for most of its surface area. You don’t actually need to ‘skeletonize’ it to save a ton of weight (and design time).

posts.name: Saatvik
posts.cooked: Could you elaborate on pocket, do you mean thin the walls by .07in. If so, what the best way to go about that, a mill?

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
What is the best pocketing design for 2x1? Technical Discussion

Mill or router is the common choice.

posts.name: Espino
posts.cooked: We buy our tubes and plates from CoastAlumin , they have 6061 alloy and they have very good shipping times

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: Probably would be even faster to find a local supplier that would do pickup. That’s what 751 has been doing for years, and it’s worked out pretty well. Shipping metal is really expensive

posts.name: Trevor Dayal (he/him)
posts.cooked:
Saatvik:

skeletonize 1x2 Aluminum Tubestock quickly

Maxpattern Maxtube is a great option for COTS tube pocketing, and it seems to interface with most cots elevator options. If you haven’t already bought the tube, this is probably the fastest route.

Skyehawk:

ames and Alex will be able to more accurately describe some of the weird stress risers you get. (All FEA needs to be taken with a grain of salt, as they would tell you, but it is a very powerful tool)

More analysis will need to be ran to fully understand boxtube effects. Unless your pocketing is far away from the boundaries (which is should, but often isn’t), you can’t just St. Venant away the boundary conditions as that’s where you get the maximum stress and the most problematic interactions. Properly clamping the boxtube between gussets is going to behave a lot differently than punching .5 holes and screwing in, or using crushblocks, or improperly bolting the tube and so on… Bolt pre-load may also significantly contribute to boundary behavior but I haven’t seen anybody run them because simulating preload is kinda annoying.

Dominick_Ferone:

Is there not concerns about all stages being too thin with 1/16th wall tube? I assumed carriage and base stage on a multistage should be more rigid and 1/8th wall.

Wall thickness doesn’t have a super strong effect on the bending strength and stiffness of the tube assuming that localized behaviors are negligible. Under proper usage, most of the forces goes directly into the sides which is just a simple beam in bending and increasing the thickness will cause only a roughlisly linear increase in strength and stiffness.Compared to increasing the outer size which will scale strength quadractically and stiffness cubically, or just avoiding the bending with proper reinforcement, which causes a very large decrease in bending stresses and deflections. The linear increase from stiffness is nothing.
